column4: asoundconf is no longer used afail , ~/.asoundrc is open to configuration if you need it
now that I searched for it, I remember having a similar issue in some previous ubuntu version
on some bios you disable the onboard audio and choose the pci card in "peripherals" or audiocodec  optional choices , then no blacklist is required , because some upgrades can defeat media balcklists
oh, good to know! I will check that after reboot later today.
kostkon: the reason I changed soundcards was very bad sound quality. reading up a bit on that revealed that the onbord sound might be responsible for that.
no, just disabled/blacklisted the onboard sound so far, right now I am checking sound quality with different sources

I'm not a pulseaudio fan , but in some cases such as pci soundcards it's needed to work with website audio like flash/flv embedded files . if you have it then pavucontrol would be a benefit for input and output settings
i think pulseaudio does a great job now, because it didn't give me any trouble in my previous ubuntu and the quality was not bad
I am still testing right now but it seems that sound quality is a whole lot better with a real soundcard (sb live!)
well if you're using the analog output then pulseaudio is another layer of audio processing which degrades the audio quality somewhat , doing 2 digital processes instead of just one thru alsa
I might be wrong about that but I believe pulseaudio yielded better quality than alsa did on the same machine.
yes, I meant just plain alsa compared to pulseaudio on top of alsa
if you like, I can report back to you on how sound is doing here

personally I use the spdif passthru with pulse using a m-audio pci card as card=0 , to the DAC on an audio amplifier and I also have the onboard audio setup/intel hda and it feeds thru the hdmi out to our tv , altho I don't use that one much
spdif is a dream of mine, but I don't have the hardware for that
